hobby.message: I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.
Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Things do seem different lately. Not much peace for small hobbies.
I clean and restore old typewriters. Every key seems louder these days.
Too many people watching, even sounds carry.
Some things are best left quiet for now.
Feels unsettled, yes. Too much noise about that graffiti near the station.
I spend evenings working on antique typewriters. It's how I stay level.
Hard to focus when the crowds gather outside my building.
Even my tools feel political now, you know.
I'll adjust. One can always clean the ribbon spools by candlelight.
Yes, atmosphere’s off—those crowds at the graffiti don’t help.
I collect and restore antique typewriters. Keeps my hands and mind steady.
Lost power in the middle of repairing an Erika last night.
Could barely see my own notes, had to finish by candlelight.
Even a small squeak draws attention lately. Odd times.
Still, there’s something calming about fixing old machines.
Definitely feels off—between the crowds and all this oversight talk.
I restore pre-System typewriters, write by hand too. Quiet resistance, maybe.
Yesterday’s blackout nearly ruined my reassembly—ink everywhere, candle wax on the keys.
It’s strange, machines like mine outlast every system and regime.
Some neighbors eye me now, especially after the graffiti incident.
Hard not to let paranoia in, but the work keeps me focused.
Found a letter jammed deep inside—date was before Halden’s time.
It’s more than just off. Feels like the city’s listening for every stray sound now.
Restoring typewriters is my sanctuary. I’ve kept a journal—handwritten—since before the BCI.
Last night, with the blackout, I finished cleaning an Erika by candlelight.
I swear, the crowds' noise outside syncs with each click of the keys.
Strange how something as simple as a typewriter draws suspicion now.
Back when I worked for the Council, these machines kept secrets better than any encrypted line.
That briefcase I keep? Full of handwritten drafts—sometimes riskier than they seem these days.
Every letter I type lately feels like a signal, not just a word.
hobby_answer: Yes, one arrived last week.
Just cleaning, nothing special.
Some people watch the news. I fix old machines.
Crowds make it loud outside in the evenings.
Not the best time for delicate work.
Picked up an Erika number six recently. No collector’s mark.
Old keys are easier to trust than new screens.
Hard to focus when the street’s full of rumors and noise.
Graffiti business near the station keeps everyone nervous.
Sometimes power cuts mess with my lamp.
Best to work when it's quiet.
Yes, an Erika—been restoring the carriage and keys.
I find old typewriters calm the mind. Habits from before.
Parts are harder to find these days, everything is tracked.
That graffiti by the station? Crowds every evening, disrupts my routine.
Building management runs observation drills now. Makes it tense to work late.
Every power cycle, I hold my breath for electricity.
Still, I get a few good hours of typing at dusk.
Found an Erika six with the Cyrillic layout, a rare pleasure.
I keep restoring—ink-stained hands, pages nobody sees.
It started as simple repair… now more escape.
Funny how the street’s been louder since the graffiti rumors.
Crowds gather, power flickers, management gets nervous—trouble for a quiet hobby.
Surveillance sweeps mean I use candlelight more.
Working in the dark brings old memories back.
Sometimes, I write sentences I’d never risk saying aloud.
Yes, an Erika six, Soviet export, which still holds up better than digital locks.
Restoring the mechanics feels like keeping history alive—at least on my desk.
My years at the Council desk trained me to notice precision. A typewriter rewards it.
Now, with rumors swirling about Halden, even my tools seem watched.
Last week’s graffiti crowds—couldn’t tune out their hope or doubt.
Power cuts hit mid-cleaning. Forced me back to candlelight—oddly familiar.
I keep paper journals because screens tell too much.
I hear the Directorate’s monitoring shop records again.
Strange to say, restoring keys and springs reminds me what’s still real.
